join.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to become a member of an organization, society, or group
join.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: When did you join the Labour Party?
I decided to join the army.
You can enjoy a sport without joining a club or belonging to a team.
join.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to begin to take part in an activity that other people are involved in
join.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Many sacrificed their weekend to join the hunt for the missing girl.
the benefits of joining our pension scheme
Church leaders have joined the campaign to end foxhunting.
join.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to go somewhere in order to be with someone or do something with them
join.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: She joined her aunt in the sitting room.
The immigrants were soon joined by their wives and children.
join.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to do something together with someone else, or as a group
join.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I invited them to join us for a glass of wine.
I’m sure you’ll all join me in thanking today’s speaker.
Parents have joined with health experts to produce a video for bereaved families.
Three police forces have joined together to buy a helicopter.
join.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to connect or fasten things together
join.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Join the two pieces of wood with strong glue.
The island is joined to the mainland by a causeway.
join.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: if two roads, rivers etc join, they come together and become connected at a particular point
join.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Finally, we arrived at Dartmouth, where the River Dart joins the sea.
the point where the two roads join
join.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: to make two things come together and stay in that position. Join is used about fixing two things together permanently, so that they form a single thing
Doctors used a metal rod to join the two pieces of bone together.
to join one thing to another, so that it stays in position. Attach  is often used when you can separate the two things later
She attached the photo to the letter with a paper clip.
The boards are attached with nails.
On the wall, attached with adhesive tape, was a New York City subway map.
to join pieces of equipment together, especially with a wire or pipe, so that electricity, gas, water etc can pass from one to another
Have you connected up the speakers to the stereo?
The hoses that connect the radiator to the engine are leaking.
to connect machines, systems, computers etc, so that electronic signals can pass from one to another
All the office PCs are linked to the main server.
join.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: a place where two parts of an object are connected or fastened together
join.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It’s been glued back together so well you can hardly see the join.
join.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to become a member of a group, team, or organization
join.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: She was invited to join the company’s board.
Turkey is not a member of the EU, but wants to join.
join.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to start working for a company or an organization
join.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: He first joined Allianz as a salesman.
She left in 1995, the year I joined.
join.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to take action together in order to achieve something
join.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: AT&T and NEC agreed to join forces to develop a new mobile telephone system.
Many small insurance companies are joining forces with other insurers.
join.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to do something with another person, company, or organization
join.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: Eight Japanese and two American companies are joining together to design communications equipment.
